bibl.title: Despatch from Henry May to William H. Seward, September 31, 1863
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

div1.p:
United States Comml Agency
at Gaboon River Sept 30th 1863

I would beg to offer you the following information. The trade in this river is free to all vessels of every country. No tonnage duties or other port dues. No vessel however is allowed to proceed more than fifteen miles up the river without a special permit from the authorities. This permit has not been granted to any vessels visiting the river since my arrival. The Captain of every vessel must deposit his ships papers. With the commandant of the "Guard Ship" immediately upon his arrival and report himself to the Commandant on shore presenting a manifest of the ships cargo and passenger list. No passenger is permited to land without permission. The Captain must give twenty four hours notice in order to obtain his discharge and receive no papers.

The trade upon this part of the African coast is increasing. The amount of rubber shipped from the Gaboon, Mooney and Moondah river for the present year greatly exceeds
that of any former year. The rubber mostly goes to England costing here about six cents per pound. The amount of Ivory exported from this place and sicenety is about the same as it was twenty years ago. The price is much higher Ivory coasts here from fifty to one hundred and fifty its her prunel according to the quality most of this reduction give through England to the Continents.
The amount of Bai Wood id equal to the demand though it is becoming scared upon the banks of the River. The principal supply being percured some distance up the River and into the interior. Most of this eventually reaches France through a great proposition is shipped in Engish vessels. Bai-Wood cost here about four hundred and fifty to per ton.
It is exceeding difficult, to obtain any reliable information in regard to the recources of the interior jealousies which exist between different duties. From the best information which I can gather in *ordu to secure the milk from which it is made destroy the vine. The French aree extending this possessions upon this Coast having recently purchased the River
river
<pb facs="20170615_111251"
and country of Bonny Payeng a large drum to the native "King" (Peppell"). They have latern possession of the Congo at least the north bank of it and also of Cape Lopey, the latter is a few miles to the South of this river. They have to the Rivero money and Mondah. Which aew situatue about fifty miles to the birth of this place emptying theur maters into Cousco bay.
I have no arrivals or olehartures of American vessels to report during the last six months.
With the highest consideration I have the honor to be your most humble and obedient servant Henry May U.S. Comml. Agt at Gaboon W. Africa
